results.content: I like the pace. The projects are well scaled. Using jquery animations are known for jank. Css animations are much smoother and more configurable. For a new developer would bring that up as a warning since the video is about knowledge foundation/fundamentals. Also, talk about why you would not want to use eval and maybe give some alternatives. A suggestion would be "use strict". All and all, so far this is solid fundamentals class.

results.content: This course is ok. I understand it's not for beginners, but there is a complete lack of instruction in a large majority of the videos. Most of the time, we are watching the instructor simply type out code which he is obviously copying from something printed out or something. There is not enough detail. I am constantly finding myself googling things for more detail or for things which aren't explained at all.  Honestly you could probably just download the course material and read the code and skip the videos. I probably wouldn't recommend this course unless you're happy doing lots of research on top of the videos.

results.content: This course is great. Really delivers on its promises. If you already have a basic understanding  of HTML, CSS, and Javascript, it will help you take your skills to the next level. It's not a beginners course, though. If you're just getting started you're probably better off starting with something else. It does skim over the basics at the very beginning, but it won't be enough to get you up to speed. This one really shines at showing you how you put it all together to create a professional looking and functional product. It's example- based, so he shows you how he builds something and explains what he does as he goes along. He doesn't really stall to teach you how certain concepts work, because I guess he assumes you are already familiar with the basic Javascript concepts. All in all, if you're already familiar with Javascript, and you want to explore the possibilities, and just want to see someone implement the functionality, I strongly recommend this course.
results.content_html: This course is great. Really delivers on its promises. If you already have a basic understanding of HTML, CSS, and Javascript, it will help you take your skills to the next level. It's not a beginners course, though. If you're just getting started you're probably better off starting with something else. It does skim over the basics at the very beginning, but it won't be enough to get you up to speed. This one really shines at showing you how you put it all together to create a professional looking and functional product. It's example- based, so he shows you how he builds something and explains what he does as he goes along. He doesn't really stall to teach you how certain concepts work, because I guess he assumes you are already familiar with the basic Javascript concepts. All in all, if you're already familiar with Javascript, and you want to explore the possibilities, and just want to see someone implement the functionality, I strongly recommend this course.

results.content: This course is an excellent project based course, but lacks sufficient didactic preparation (i.e. the why behind the how).  A course that compliments this course with good didactic instruction is JQuery & Ajax for Beginners - The Definitive Guide.  Together, you will develop a solid understanding of Jquery.
results.content_html: This course is an excellent project based course, but lacks sufficient didactic preparation (i.e. the why behind the how). A course that compliments this course with good didactic instruction is JQuery & Ajax for Beginners - The Definitive Guide. Together, you will develop a solid understanding of Jquery.

results.content:
There is no preparation. He should break down the code into steps by writing comments for the steps. Then, start writing the code.

Often, he keeps coding. Instead, make a small testable change, verify its working in the browser, then add code for the next change. But, he writes a lot of code, then realizes he made a mistake and then fixes it.

He hardly responds to questions. If you ask him about your own solution to the problem, then his responses are like ok, great, nice, good work etc. He does not offer any valuable insight into why your solution is better or bad.

No wonder this course was offered on discount.  A 90%+ for a 100ish $ discount suggests that the course is not that great. I would not mind paying 100+ $ for these courses provided the instructor took pains to make it organized and answered our questions. 

As usual, udemy has failed. I am only here because there are no other useful alternatives.

As usual, udemy has failed. I am only here because there are no other useful alternatives.

results.content: I really enjoyed the course — it covers a lot of cool applications of JavaScript and jQuery. While I learned a lot, the narrator is light on explanations for coding choices. Helping someone to be autonomous as a developer requires a bit more than just showing the coding live and sometimes I got a bit lost (despite having a good understanding already). This would be worse for someone relatively new. Despite this, I gave 4 stars because the course did give me a lot of insight into coding for live applications.

Helping someone to be autonomous as a developer requires a bit more than just showing the coding live and sometimes I got a bit lost (despite having a good understanding already). This would be worse for someone relatively new. Despite this, I gave 4 stars because the course did give me a lot of insight into coding for live applications.

results.content:
When learning I find Eduonix's project based tutorials far more engaging than straight video lectures. The tutor for this set of projects is well up to standard and the course has plainly been through iteration.  
As of January 2017 the external apis needed so far (to project 3) still conform to the videos. 
Five stars up to now.

results.content:
Good Course. 9/10 projects are jQuery and not Vanilla JS which I expected. But a good course to learn jQuery. I gave 1 extra star for
1.) Mini XAMPP tutorial
2.) Mini Git, Github tutorial.
3.) How to publish your plugin on jQuery registry (which is not possible now that the registry is read-only. Eduonix should update this lecture. but otherwise i had great fun learning npm on my own which is basically what programming is all about.)
4.) Mobile jQuery

A good course. I learned a lot and had a lot of fun creating the projects.

results.content: Excellent job!! Thanks! Please more jquery classes more more !! However the typing is way to fast and more explanation on certain things otherwise I love it man!! Thanks for all you do for us!!

results.content: Excellent!  Pulls all the elements needed to create the javascript/jquery example at a good pace, not too slow and not too fast.  He explains what he is doing as he's going, and he tests after each new chunk of code--what a wonderful pointer for programmers to remember whether we're novices or experienced!  I would definitely recommend that you know at the least the basics of HTML5, CSS and JS (and when to use single quotes, double quotes, slashes, parens, semi-colons, etc.) before starting so as to keep up, but you'll certainly add to your knowledge of each.  For me, creating a project is the best way to learn programming concepts.  Just finished this fantastic course, and if I could give it 10 stars, I would!
results.content_html: Excellent! Pulls all the elements needed to create the javascript/jquery example at a good pace, not too slow and not too fast. He explains what he is doing as he's going, and he tests after each new chunk of code--what a wonderful pointer for programmers to remember whether we're novices or experienced! I would definitely recommend that you know at the least the basics of HTML5, CSS and JS (and when to use single quotes, double quotes, slashes, parens, semi-colons, etc.) before starting so as to keep up, but you'll certainly add to your knowledge of each. For me, creating a project is the best way to learn programming concepts. Just finished this fantastic course, and if I could give it 10 stars, I would!

results.content: This course covered many practical exercises to work through using html, css, javascript, and jquery - I actually learned from many different design ideas and coding, and from how html, css, js and jquery interact/work together.  This is way better than just learning html or just learning javascript.  My one issue was closed captioning - although many courses were closed captioned, there were many about 1/3 that was not.
results.content_html: This course covered many practical exercises to work through using html, css, javascript, and jquery - I actually learned from many different design ideas and coding, and from how html, css, js and jquery interact/work together. This is way better than just learning html or just learning javascript. My one issue was closed captioning - although many courses were closed captioned, there were many about 1/3 that was not.

results.content: There is a lot of material covered by this course.  In certain projects the instructor explains why he's using certain functions; in others he just bangs away at the keyboard and types out code.  Considering it's a fairly new course it's surprising that some functions already have been deprecated and it's annoying that the Git Hub publishing is shut to new entries, so much of project #7 (Creating a jQuery Plug-In) is irrelevant.  It would help to update this section.

In certain projects the instructor explains why he's using certain functions; in others he just bangs away at the keyboard and types out code. Considering it's a fairly new course it's surprising that some functions already have been deprecated and it's annoying that the Git Hub publishing is shut to new entries, so much of project #7 (Creating a jQuery Plug-In) is irrelevant. results.content:
As I just get in jQuery, I knew nothing about it. I took this course with the purpose to understand how things work, how elements interact with each other, and there the author's comments were pure. I wished author could spend more seconds in explanations. It felt like we must rush for code writing and after sit alone and summarize how things work.

In the other course I took "PHP & mySQL projects" the new elements and code overall were more explained, so I really felt the difference.

results.content: Although I am just a beginner programmer, I understand basic concepts and syntax to an extent. Granted he goes slowly and explains it for us. But there are moments where he just dumps obscure methods and functions YOU HAVE NEVER EVEN HEARD OF. Then he just waltzes pass them without dwelling on what the parameter or what the function itself would do the application as a whole. In addition, most of the code I end up copying turns out to be buggy on my end, but guess what? I CANNOT DEBUG CODE I DON'T UNDERSTAND to begin with.

results.content:
Good things:
- Well documentation, well resouce files
- Every section have their clearly purposes to show how we can use javascript/jQuery in various goals and various ways.
- Strongly knowledge about javascript/jQuery from the instructor.
Need improvements:
- I think this course is not for beginners to follow, for example in the Section about youtube API. It's very hard for the beginner to follow among the concepts about API, google developer tools, json objects... It's will be great if you explain more details about these.
- This is the course about javascript/jQuery. So, we don't need so much time to spend on watching typing HTML, CSS tasks repeated every sections because the course issued source files already.
- Sometimes, the instructor made mistake on the syntax. I don't know he did these intensionally to remind the viewers to remember carefully about syntax. But, don't do these so much, otherwise it brings the negative effects
Conclusion: this is a useful & valueable course.

results.content: very well explained in a comprehencive way

results.content:
The projects seem quite practical and interesting. I found that if I opened my editor and typed the code along as the instructor did, I learned a good bit. BUT, any actual learning of JS, jQuery or CSS that takes place does so without any help from the instructor. He almost never explains why he's doing a particular thing. He doesn't explain CSS at all. (Even the use of * to reset is completely ignored; he just types it without a clear explanation.) As a result, I would definitely NOT recommend this course for a beginner. You really need more than a basic grasp of both JS and CSS to get anywhere. 

I found I had to pause the lecture frequently to look up the exact syntax and meaning of code he was simply typing very fast and not commenting on at all. Thus, the learning approach here is more "watch me do this" than it is "here's how you do this and why."

The material is well suited to an early intermediate designer/developer and if you take the time to type in the code rather than just loading the course files you can download, you'll probably learn a certain amount by osmosis.
results.content_html:
The projects seem quite practical and interesting. I found that if I opened my editor and typed the code along as the instructor did, I learned a good bit. BUT, any actual learning of JS, jQuery or CSS that takes place does so without any help from the instructor. He almost never explains why he's doing a particular thing. He doesn't explain CSS at all. (Even the use of * to reset is completely ignored; he just types it without a clear explanation.) As a result, I would definitely NOT recommend this course for a beginner. You really need more than a basic grasp of both JS and CSS to get anywhere.

I found I had to pause the lecture frequently to look up the exact syntax and meaning of code he was simply typing very fast and not commenting on at all. Thus, the learning approach here is more "watch me do this" than it is "here's how you do this and why."

The material is well suited to an early intermediate designer/developer and if you take the time to type in the code rather than just loading the course files you can download, you'll probably learn a certain amount by osmosis.

results.content: Much of this course is not updated and therefore newer versions of API's and Javascript libraries no longer work as instructed. The course starts to delve into areas where the topics get more advanced but there is no explanation as to how some of these more advanced topics work. And the course feels very old fashioned including the use of PHP and older ways of tackling web development problems. Overall, very disappointed and moving on to other courses.

results.content:
This is a great course that allows me to improve javascript skills by practicing many projects. It is easy for me to learn how to use javascript code in real world.
But if the lecturer can elaborate more details and how some functions work, that would be much better. Sometimes I just don't really know how those functions work and why use them. Then I have to google it by myself. 
Overall this is very helpful course. I recommend to adopt this course after learning some basic JavaScript & jQuery courses.

results.content: This course is first of all amazing in the sense that I learned a lot. However, I have great foundational knowledge of coding and hence, i did not need any help at all even when things were a bit off. I must say this course further extends your knowledge of jQuery and javascript. I would recommend this course to anyone who has a good programming knowledge and wants to learn front-end. Very practical learning experience and I am grateful and fortunate to take this course. Thanks Brad for explaining a lot of concepts as much as you can. The only project in the course that was bit difficult to understand was the jQuery mobile app. There were a lot of new concepts in that project that I had to use external resources to understand. Overall, a very good learning experience. I still rate this course 5 star since I learned a lot.

results.content:
The course is definitely useful and rather good. If there are any suggestions that I might recommend...:
- go to the current state of the app more frequently so that we can see what the latest changes actually do (especially for CSS, otherwise you can just skip the CSS part altogether)
- if you can find a way, show html and js/css files in parallel while you are editing the latter (so we can see classes and ids)
- cleaner code. I feel like sometimes the easier path you take is actually more complicated. Using functions to write cleaner and easier to read code doesn't take that much longer and it makes for a better understanding.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I am very pleased with this course. Here is why:
1. Projects are good and well organized and the source code is downloadable, clear and concise
2. The mp4 video training files are downloadable and of good quality.  Using VLC for viewing videos that have been downloaded, I can speed up and slow down the course when needed. 1X speed is too slow most of the time.
3. Instructor is clear, confident and easily understood. He shows good coding without going into too much detail. Anything I needed more information on, I could easily google.

I really enjoy this project based learning. The student is left with understandable

results.content:
This is an excellent course.  I wouldn't recommend it for complete beginners as the instructor doesn't spend much time explaining what things are doing.  It's more appropriate for someone who already has a grasp of some JavaScript/jQuery basics (e.g. from taking another Udemy course)).  If you already understand the basics building these 10 projects will give you a lot of practice of using different features of jQuery.

The course could be better if the instructor spent just a little more time explaining some of the more complicated features - I think adding more explanatory comments would be helpful.
results.content_html:
This is an excellent course. I wouldn't recommend it for complete beginners as the instructor doesn't spend much time explaining what things are doing. It's more appropriate for someone who already has a grasp of some JavaScript/jQuery basics (e.g. from taking another Udemy course)). If you already understand the basics building these 10 projects will give you a lot of practice of using different features of jQuery.

The course could be better if the instructor spent just a little more time explaining some of the more complicated features - I think adding more explanatory comments would be helpful.

results.content: In this course you will basically copy everything the teacher is typing, but there is no explanation as to why he is doing it. In other words, concepts are not explained. If you want to copy and paste from the teacher's notes (finished files are available for download), you'll have all the finished projects. However, understanding  the logic behind the steps are another thing. I felt this course fell short of teaching students the "why" behind the "what".

results.content: This course does exactly what it says. It teaches you the skills that you needed. It has a good mix of both video and text, with benefits from added reading if you wish to Learn deeper. The course’s ‘no rush’ attitude really fits into my busy life style. The way Instructer teaches makes it very easy to pick up from where you left off a few days ago. I also like the way udemy reminds me if it has been a few days since I last did anything on the course. Overall, I would definitely recommend this course.

results.content: I'm about halfway through this course, and I'm really enjoying it. The learning projects seem to reflect real-world usefulness, and there are lots of other tips to pick up along the way with things like css (which I'm also new to). The instructor has a style I prefer - straight to the point, clear with explanations and obviously knows the subject inside out. My only criticism - and this might be because I'm also only learning other web tech - is that he sometimes races through putting everything together without explaining any of the decisions that have gone before - you can tell that he's following a "here's one I made earlier" script. But overall, great - I would recommend it for a beginner to JQuery provided they've at least dabbled in javascript, html, css.
results.content_html: I'm about halfway through this course, and I'm really enjoying it. The learning projects seem to reflect real-world usefulness, and there are lots of other tips to pick up along the way with things like css (which I'm also new to). The instructor has a style I prefer - straight to the point, clear with explanations and obviously knows the subject inside out. My only criticism - and this might be because I'm also only learning other web tech - is that he sometimes races through putting everything together without explaining any of the decisions that have gone before - you can tell that he's following a "here's one I made earlier" script. But overall, great - I would recommend it for a beginner to JQuery provided they've at least dabbled in javascript, html, css.

results.content: The presentation is professional and very clear. There is a lot of material in this course and each project explores different but very important functionality. As my first course purely covering JavaScript, but having done lots of backend and styling previously, I think this course was great and I learned a lot. The only criticism I have is I would have liked to see more use of jQuery with API's, as in the YouTube API project (which appears to require updating as of April 2016).
results.content_html: The presentation is professional and very clear. There is a lot of material in this course and each project explores different but very important functionality. As my first course purely covering JavaScript, but having done lots of backend and styling previously, I think this course was great and I learned a lot. The only criticism I have is I would have liked to see more use of jQuery with API's, as in the YouTube API project (which appears to require updating as of April 2016).

- cons

    The instructor doesn't explain a lot, most of the time he just reads what he types.
    It could have better examples; more realistic.
    Written in EcmaScript 5 so this is kinda outdated or will be in the short future.   (depends when are you reading this)
results.content_html:
- pros
Good material for learning.
Great for non-beginners.
Has Jquery Mobile good if you want mobile development.
- cons
The course is quite boring.
The instructor doesn't explain a lot, most of the time he just reads what he types.
It could have better examples; more realistic.
Written in EcmaScript 5 so this is kinda outdated or will be in the short future. (depends when are you reading this)

results.content:
I would recommend this course for people that at least have studied theoretical base of Javascript and JQuery, because without it it will be hard for you to completely understand some aspects of this course, even tho this course covers some of the basic stuff of jQuery to explain how things work, but it's not enough if you want to be a competent developer, to be such you will have to learn about javascript and JQuery for yourself. W3Schools is a great free resource to get your grip on javascript and jQuery. Here are 2 links that you must learn if you want to get maximum of this course:
http://www.w3schools.com/js/default.asp
http://www.w3schools.com/jquery/default.asp

Instructor is great, I really like the way he shows and explains things, I've already passed on of his courses(10 projects in PHP) and I really liked it, it was very useful.
results.content_html:

results.content: Be ready to press pause, the pace of this course is fast. You'll also need to do some of your own research to fully understand some of the code being implemented here.
